revisions.rev:
[[File:Hs-2009-23-crop.jpg|thumb|[[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]] image of the scar taken on July 23 showing a blemish of about {{convert|8,000|km|mi}} long<ref>{{cite news|author=Dennis Overbye |title=Hubble Takes Snapshot of Jupiterâs âBlack Eyeâ |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/25/science/space/25hubble.html?ref=science|date=2009-07-24|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-25}}</ref><ref name="hubblesite"/>]] [[File:Jupiter impact jul2009.jpg|thumb|A picture of the 2009 impact mark captured by NASA's Infrared Telescope Facility in Mauna Kea, Hawaii]] [[File:Keck image of Jupiter impact.jpg|thumb|Large impact observed with Keck II telescope and its near-infrared camera at Mauna Kea on July 20 11:20 UT]] [[File:The Keck Subaru and Infrared obervatories.JPG|thumb|right|[[W. M. Keck Observatory|Keck Observatory]] (the two in the middle) and [[NASA Infrared Telescope Facility]] (right) at [[Mauna Kea Observatory|Mauna Kea]], [[Hawaii]]]]
The '''2009 Jupiter [[impact event]]''', occasionally referred to as the '''Wesley impact''', was a July 2009 impact on [[Jupiter]] that caused a black spot in the planet's atmosphere. The spot was similar in area to the planet's [[Atmosphere of Jupiter#Oval_BA|Little Red Spot]], approximately the size of the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref name="berkeleypr">[http://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2009/07/21_bruise.shtml Jupiter pummeled, leaving bruise the size of the Pacific Ocean]. University of California, Berkeley press release, July 21, 2009.</ref> The impacter is estimated to have been about 200 to 500 meters in diameter.<ref name="PR2011"/>
==Discovery== [[amateur astronomy|Amateur astronomer]] Anthony Wesley discovered the impact at approximately 13:30 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] on 19 July 2009 (almost exactly 15 years after the Jupiter impact of [[comet Shoemaker-Levy 9]], or SL9). He was at his home [[observatory]] just outside [[Murrumbateman, New South Wales|Murrumbateman]], [[New South Wales]], [[Australia]], using stacked images on a {{convert|14.5|in|cm|adj=on|1}} diameter [[reflecting telescope]] equipped with a low light machine vision video camera attached to the telescope.<ref>{{cite news|author=Mackey, Robert|title=Amateur Finds New Earth-Sized Blot on Jupiter|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/07/21/amateur-astronomer-finds-new-earth-size-impact-mark-on-jupiter/|date=July 21, 2009|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-07-21}}</ref> Wesley stated that
{{quote|When first seen close to the limb (and in poor conditions) it was only a vaguely dark spot, I [thought] likely to be just a normal dark polar storm. However as it rotated further into view, and the conditions improved I suddenly realised that it wasn't just dark, it was ''black'' in all channels, meaning it was truly a black spot.<ref>{{cite web|author=Wesley, Anthony|title=Impact mark on Jupiter, 19th July 2009|url=http://jupiter.samba.org/jupiter-impact.html|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5iTsIBdEs|archivedate=2009-07-22|publisher=(jupiter.samba.org)|accessdate=2009-07-21}}</ref>}}
Wesley sent an e-mail to others including the [[NASA]] [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] in [[Pasadena, California]] reporting his observations.<ref>{{cite news|author=O'Loughlin, Toni and agencies|title=Amateur astronomer spots Earth-size scar on Jupiter|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/science/2009/jul/21/jupiter-scar-comet-asteroid-crash|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=2009-07-21 | location=London | date=2009-07-21}}</ref>
==Findings== [[Paul Kalas]] and collaborators confirmed the sighting. They had time on the [[W. M. Keck Observatory|Keck II]] telescope in [[Hawaii]], and had been planning to observe [[Fomalhaut b]], but they spent some of their time looking at the Jupiter impact.<ref name="keckpr">[http://keckobservatory.org/index.php/news/jupiters_adds_a_feature/ Jupiter adds a feature]. Keck Observatory observations, July 21, 2009</ref> Infrared observation by Keck and the [[NASA Infrared Telescope Facility]] (IRTF)<ref name="berkeleypr"/> at Mauna Kea showed a bright spot where the impact took place, indicating the impact warmed a 190 million square km area of the lower atmosphere at 305 W, 57 S near Jupiter's south pole.<ref name="berkeleypr"/>
The spot's prominence indicates that it is composed of high-altitude aerosols similar to those seen during the SL9 impact.<ref name="keckpr"/> Using [[Near-infrared#Different_regions_in_the_infrared|near-infrared]] wavelengths and the IRTF, Glenn Orton and his team detected bright upwelling particles in the planet's upper atmosphere and using mid-infrared wavelengths, found possible extra emission of [[ammonia]] gas.<ref name=Martinez>{{cite web|author=Martinez, Carolina|title=New NASA Images Indicate Object Hits Jupiter|url=http://www.nasa.gov/topics/solarsystem/features/jup-20090720.html|date=July 20, 2009|publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=2009-07-21}}</ref>
The force of the explosion on Jupiter was thousands of times more powerful than the suspected comet or asteroid that [[Tunguska event|exploded over the Tunguska]] River Valley in Siberia in June 1908.<ref name="hubblesite">{{cite web |title=Hubble Captures Rare Jupiter Collision |publisher=Hubblesite (STScI-2009-23) |url=http://hubblesite.org/newscenter/archive/releases/2009/23/full |date=2009-07-24 |accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> (This would be over a million times more powerful than [[Atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki|the bomb dropped on Hiroshima]].)<ref>{{Cite book | last = Longo | first = Giuseppe | contribution = The Tunguska event |editor-last = Bobrowsky | editor-first = Peter T. | editor2-last = Rickman | editor2-first = Hans | title = Comet/Asteroid Impacts and Human Society, An Interdisciplinary Approach | chapter = 18 | pages = 303â330 | publisher = Springer-Verlag | place = Berlin Heidelberg New York | publication-date = 2007 | contribution-url = http://www-th.bo.infn.it/tunguska/Asteroids-Chapter-18.pdf | isbn=3-540-32709-6 | year = 2007 | postscript = .}}. Accessed 2009-07-27. [http://www.webcitation.org/5icderdjK Archived] 2009-07-29.</ref>
Astronomers will further observe the impact area with a variety of instruments, including the Keck<ref name="keckpr"/> and the [[Hubble Space Telescope]]'s [[STS-125|recently installed]] [[WFC3|Wide Field Camera 3]].<ref name="berkeleypr"/>
==Impactor== The object that hit Jupiter was not identified before Wesley discovered the impact. A 2003 paper estimated comets with a diameter larger than 1.5 kilometers impact Jupiter about every 90 to 500 years,<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Kevin |last=Zahnle |first2=Paul |last2=Schenk |first3=Harold |last3=Levison |first4=Luke |last4=Dones |year=2003 |month= |title=Cratering rates in the outer Solar System |journal=[[Icarus (journal)|Icarus]] |volume= 163|issue=163 |pages=263â289 |url=http://lasp.colorado.edu/~espoclass/homework/5830_2008_homework/Zahnle2003CrateringRates.pdf |format=pdf |bibcode= 2003Icar..163..263Z|issn= |quote=1.5-km-diameter comets is currently N(d > 1.5 km) = 0.005 +0.006 -0.003 per annum|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5icdGOsFF|archivedate=2009-07-29|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-07-27|doi=10.1016/S0019-1035(03)00048-4 |postscript=.}}</ref> while a 1997 survey suggested that the astronomer [[Giovanni Domenico Cassini|Cassini]] may have recorded an impact in 1690.<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Isshi |last=Tabe |first2=Jun-ichi |last2=Watanabe |first3=Michiwo |last3=Jimbo |year=1997 |month=February |title=Discovery of a Possible Impact SPOT on Jupiter Recorded in 1690 |journal=Publ. of the Astronomical Society of Japan |volume=49 |issue= |pages=L1âL5 |bibcode=1997PASJ...49L...1T |issn= |quote=Jupiter has been continuously monitored for almost 400 yr |postscript=.}}</ref>
Given the size of the SL9 impacters,<ref name="sl9-size">{{cite web |title=Comet Shoemaker-Levy 9 Fragment Size |publisher=Lunar and Planetary Institute |author=D. A. Crawford |url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc97/pdf/1351.PDF |accessdate=2009-07-22}}</ref> it is likely that this object was less than one kilometer in diameter.<ref name="hubblesite"/><ref name="gemini">{{cite web |title=Surprise Collision on Jupiter Captured by Gemini Telescope |publisher=Gemini Observatory |url=http://www.gemini.edu/node/11300 |accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> <!-- <ref name="Tedmanson">{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/science/article6721504.ece|title=Backyard astronomer discovers black spot on Jupiter|last=Tedmanson|first=Sophie|date=2009-07-22|publisher=[[The Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-22 | location=London}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/science/space/5882014/Planet-Jupiter-hit-by-object-which-left-a-dent-the-size-of-Earth.html|title=Planet Jupiter hit by object which left a dent the size of Earth |date=2009-07-21|source=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2009-07-22 | location=London}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE56K0ZV20090721|title=Giant "scar" on Jupiter spotted by amateur stargazer |date=2009-07-21|source=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2009-07-22 | first=Rob | last=Taylor}}</ref> <ref name="Than">{{cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2009/07/090721-jupiter-impact-spot.html|title=PHOTO: Jupiter Impact Creates Huge New Spot|last=Than|first=Ker|date=2009-07-21|publisher=[[National Geographic]]|accessdate=2009-07-22}}</ref> <ref name="Johnson">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/science/la-sci-jupiter22-2009jul22,0,5215362.story|title= 'Incredible' new scar is spreading on Jupiter|last=Johnson, Jr.|first=John |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=2009-07-22|date=2009-07-22}} </ref> --> Finding water at the site would indicate that the impacter was a comet,<ref name="perlman">Perlman, David. "[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/07/23/MN5I18TT7U.DTL Glowing scar is revealing Jupiter's secrets]" ''San Francisco Chronicle, 23 July 2009.</ref> as opposed to an asteroid or a very small, icy moon.<ref name="Grossman">{{cite news|url=http://www.newscientist.com/article/dn17491-jupiter-sports-new-bruise-from-impact.html|title= Jupiter sports new 'bruise' from impact |last=Grossman|first=Lisa|date=2009-07-21|publisher=[[New Scientist]]|accessdate=2009-07-22}}</ref> At first it was believed that the object was more likely to be a comet since comets generally have more planet crossing orbits.<ref name="Hergenrother">{{cite web |title=More on the Jupiter Impact |author=[http://transientsky.wordpress.com/about/ Carl Hergenrother]|url=http://transientsky.wordpress.com/2009/07/21/more-on-the-jupiter-impact/ |date=2009-07-21 |accessdate=2009-07-24}}</ref> At the distance of Jupiter (5.2 AU) most small comets are not close enough to the Sun to be very [[Coma (cometary)|active]], and so would be hard to detect.<ref name="Hergenrother"/> Small kilometer-sized asteroids would also be hard to detect, however, and recent work by Orton et al. and Hammel et al. has strongly suggested the impacter was an asteroid, as it left only one impact site, did not reduce Jovian decametric radiation emission by contributing significant dust to the Jovian magnetosphere, and produced high altitude dusty debris full of silica, very different than what was produced by SL9.{{citation needed|date=April 2010}}
As of 2011, the impacter is believed to have been an asteroid with a diameter of about 200 to 500 meters.<ref name="PR2011">{{cite web |date=January 26, 2011 |title=Asteroids Ahoy! Jupiter Scar Likely from Rocky Body |publisher=News and Features @ NASA/JPL |author=Jia-Rui C. Cook |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.cfm?release=2011-028 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref>
===Visibility=== Assuming it was an inactive comet (or asteroid) about 1 km in diameter, this object would have been no brighter than about [[apparent magnitude]] 25.<ref name="Hergenrother"/> (Jupiter shines about 130 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]] times brighter than a 25th magnitude object.)<ref>([[Apparent magnitude|5th root of 100]])^(25-(-2.8))=131 billion (1.3E+11)</ref> Most asteroid surveys which use a wide field of view do not see fainter than about magnitude 22 (which is 16x brighter than magnitude 25).<ref name="Hergenrother"/> Even detecting satellites less than 10 km in diameter orbiting Jupiter is difficult and requires some of the best telescopes in the world.<ref name="Sheppard2003">{{cite web |title=New Satellites of Jupiter Discovered in 2003 |publisher=Carnegie Institution (Department of Terrestrial Magnetism) |author=[[Scott S. Sheppard]] |url=http://www.dtm.ciw.edu/users/sheppard/satellites/jup2003.html |accessdate=2009-07-23}}</ref> It is only since 1999 with the discovery of [[Callirrhoe (moon)|Callirrhoe]] that astronomers have been able to discover many of [[Moons_of_Jupiter#Table|Jupiter's smallest moons]].<ref name="moon1999">{{cite web |title=New moon of Jupiter found |publisher=SpaceFlight Now (University of Arizona News Release) |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/news/n0007/21jovianmoon/ |accessdate=2009-07-23}}</ref>
==June 3, 2010== {{main|2010 Jupiter impact event}} On June 3, 2010, Anthony Wesley discovered another impact event, smaller than the previous observed impacts.<ref name=impact2010/> The 2010 impact was then discovered to have also been captured on video by amateur astronomer Christopher Go in the [[Philippines]].<ref name=impact2010>{{cite web|url=http://www.astronomy.com/asy/default.aspx?c=a&id=9918| title=Another impact on Jupiter| date=2010-06-04| first=Michael| last=Bakich| publisher=[[Astronomy Magazine]] online| accessdate=2010-06-04}}</ref>
